title: Quiz 8: Epidemiology
description: NCK 2025 Predictions for Epidemiology (Set 5). Contains 50 questions.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of epidemiology?

options.text: ) To study disease distribution and determinants in populations

questions.explanation: Epidemiology focuses on understanding how diseases are distributed in populations and what factors determine or influence this distribution, which is essential for public health planning and disease prevention.

questions.question: Which measure best describes the frequency of a disease at a specific point in time?
questions.explanation: Prevalence refers to the proportion of individuals who have a disease at a specific point or period, indicating disease burden in a population.

questions.question: Incidence rate is best defined as:

options.text: ) Number of new cases in a population over a period of time
) Total cases existing at a point in time
) Number of deaths due to a disease
) Proportion of cases that result in death

questions.explanation: Incidence measures new cases occurring in a population during a specified time, which helps understand disease risk and dynamics.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a cohort study?

options.text: ) Follows subjects over time to observe outcomes

questions.explanation: Cohort studies are observational and do not involve random allocation; this is a feature of experimental studies like randomized controlled trials.

questions.question: What does a case-control study compare?

options.text: ) Exposure status between diseased and non-diseased individuals

questions.explanation: Case-control studies compare past exposure history in individuals with disease (cases) and without disease (controls) to identify risk factors.

questions.question: Which measure is most appropriate to estimate risk in a cohort study?
questions.explanation: Relative risk compares the risk of disease in exposed versus unexposed groups, commonly used in cohort studies.

questions.question: In epidemiology, the term "endemic" means:

options.text: ) A disease occurring at low rates in a population
) A disease constantly present in a population
) A sudden increase in disease cases

questions.explanation: Endemic diseases maintain a steady presence within a specific geographic area or population.

questions.question: Which of the following best defines a "pandemic"?

options.text: ) Disease outbreak confined to a single location
) A disease affecting many countries or continents

questions.explanation: A pandemic refers to an epidemic that has spread across countries or continents, affecting a large number of people globally.

questions.question: The term "mortality rate" refers to:

options.text: ) Number of new cases of a disease
) Number of deaths in a population over a time period
) Proportion of people cured from a disease
) Number of people exposed to a risk factor

questions.explanation: Mortality rate quantifies deaths in a specified population and time frame.

questions.question: Which of the following describes "confounding"?

options.text: ) A factor that distorts the association between exposure and outcome

questions.explanation: Confounding occurs when a third variable influences both the exposure and outcome, leading to a misleading association.

questions.question: The "attack rate" is best described as:

options.text: ) The rate of new cases in a population over a long period
) The proportion of people who become ill in a defined group during an outbreak
) The death rate from a disease
) The rate of recovery from an infection

questions.explanation: Attack rate is the proportion of exposed individuals who develop disease during a specific outbreak or exposure period.

questions.question: The "case fatality rate" measures:

options.text: ) Risk of dying among all exposed individuals
) The proportion of deaths among diagnosed cases of a disease
) Mortality rate in the general population

questions.explanation: Case fatality rate is the percentage of cases that result in death, reflecting disease severity.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a measure of association?
questions.explanation: Incidence rate measures frequency, not the strength of association between exposure and outcome.

questions.question: Bias in epidemiological studies refers to:

options.text: ) Systematic error that distorts study results

questions.explanation: Bias is a systematic error affecting the validity of study findings.

questions.question: A "cross-sectional study" measures:

options.text: ) Exposure and disease status at a single point in time

questions.explanation: Cross-sectional studies assess exposure and outcome simultaneously in a population.

questions.question: In an epidemic curve, the x-axis usually represents:
questions.explanation: Epidemic curves plot the number of cases against time to visualize outbreak progression.

questions.question: Which of these is a characteristic of a randomized controlled trial (RCT)?

options.text: ) Random assignment of exposure or intervention

questions.explanation: RCTs involve random allocation to interventions to minimize bias and establish causality.

questions.question: What is "herd immunity"?

options.text: ) Immunity in a population that reduces disease spread when many are immune

questions.explanation: Herd immunity protects populations when a critical mass is immune, reducing disease transmission.

questions.question: Which factor is an example of a "host factor" in disease epidemiology?
questions.explanation: Host factors relate to the characteristics of the person that affect disease susceptibility.

questions.question: "Incubation period" is defined as:

options.text: ) Time between exposure and symptom onset
) Time from disease diagnosis to recovery

questions.explanation: Incubation period is the latency time before clinical signs appear after exposure.

questions.question: Which of the following study designs is best suited to study rare diseases?
questions.explanation: Case-control studies efficiently investigate rare diseases by selecting cases and controls.

questions.question: The term "surveillance" in epidemiology refers to:

options.text: ) Continuous systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data

questions.explanation: Surveillance monitors disease trends to guide public health interventions.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of primary prevention?
questions.explanation: Primary prevention aims to prevent disease occurrence, with vaccination being a key example.

questions.question: The "population at risk" is best described as:

options.text: ) People exposed and susceptible to the disease

questions.explanation: Population at risk includes individuals who can potentially develop the disease.

questions.question: A "confounding variable" must:

options.text: ) Be related only to the exposure
) Be related only to the outcome
) Be associated with both exposure and outcome but not be a causal factor

questions.explanation: Confounders distort the true exposure-disease relationship because they influence both.

questions.question: Which measure is best suited for assessing the risk of developing a disease in a population over a specified period?
questions.explanation: Incidence rate measures the number of new cases occurring in a population during a specific time period and is best suited for assessing the risk of developing a disease. Prevalence includes both new and existing cases, while mortality and case fatality rates relate to death outcomes rather than risk of developing disease.

questions.question: Which of the following study designs is most appropriate to investigate the cause of a rare disease?
questions.explanation: Case-control studies are efficient for rare diseases because they start with cases (those with disease) and compare them to controls. Cohort studies require following a large population over time, which can be inefficient for rare diseases. Cross-sectional studies cannot establish causality, and randomized trials are often unethical or impractical for rare diseases.

questions.question: What does the term "confounding" refer to in epidemiology?

options.text: ) A variable associated with both exposure and outcome, distorting the true association
) A bias introduced by selective participation

questions.explanation: Confounding occurs when an extraneous factor is related to both the exposure and outcome, potentially misleading the apparent association. This can be controlled through study design or statistical methods.

questions.question: Which measure provides the proportion of deaths among diagnosed cases of a disease?
questions.explanation: Case fatality rate measures the proportion of deaths within a defined group of diagnosed cases, reflecting disease severity. Mortality rate measures deaths in a general population, incidence is about new cases, and prevalence is about total cases.

questions.question: In a cohort study, what is the main advantage over a case-control study?

options.text: ) Can calculate incidence and relative risk directly

questions.explanation: Cohort studies follow exposed and unexposed groups over time, allowing direct calculation of incidence rates and relative risks. Case-control studies cannot calculate incidence directly and estimate odds ratios instead.

questions.question: Which term describes the proportion of a population with a disease at a specific point in time?
questions.explanation: Point prevalence measures the proportion of people with a disease at a particular moment, while period prevalence covers a time span. Incidence rate measures new cases, and attack rate is a form of incidence used in outbreaks.

questions.question: What type of bias occurs when participants are lost to follow-up in a longitudinal study?
questions.explanation: Attrition bias arises when participants drop out during a study, potentially leading to systematic differences between those who remain and those lost, which may bias results.

questions.question: Which epidemiological term refers to the strength of association between an exposure and an outcome?
questions.explanation: Relative risk measures the strength of association by comparing incidence in exposed vs unexposed groups. Sensitivity and specificity relate to test performance, and prevalence describes disease frequency.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of randomization in a clinical trial?

options.text: ) To reduce confounding by equal distribution of known and unknown factors

questions.explanation: Randomization aims to evenly distribute confounders across treatment groups, minimizing bias and allowing causal inference. Blinding is a separate process, and randomization does not directly affect sample size or speed.

questions.question: Which of the following is a non-modifiable risk factor?
questions.explanation: Age is non-modifiable, meaning it cannot be changed. Smoking, hypertension, and inactivity are modifiable risk factors that can be targeted in prevention efforts.

questions.question: Which type of study provides the highest level of evidence for causality?
questions.explanation: RCTs minimize bias through randomization and control conditions, providing the strongest evidence for causality compared to observational studies.

questions.question: What does "incidence density" take into account that simple incidence proportion does not?
questions.explanation: Incidence density measures new cases per unit of person-time, accounting for varying follow-up times, unlike incidence proportion which ignores time dimension.

questions.question: Which bias occurs when participants remember past exposures differently depending on their disease status?
questions.explanation: Recall bias happens in retrospective studies when cases may recall exposures more accurately or differently than controls, affecting validity.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of primary prevention?
questions.explanation: Primary prevention aims to prevent disease occurrence (e.g., vaccination). Screening is secondary prevention (early detection), rehabilitation is tertiary (manage established disease), and chemotherapy is treatment.

questions.question: In epidemiology, "specificity" of a diagnostic test refers to:

options.text: ) Ability to identify those with the disease
) Ability to identify those without the disease
) Proportion of true positives among positives

questions.explanation: Specificity is the test’s ability to correctly identify those who do NOT have the disease (true negatives), reducing false positives.

questions.question: The "ecological fallacy" refers to:

options.text: ) Incorrectly assuming group-level associations apply at individual level

questions.explanation: Ecological fallacy occurs when conclusions about individuals are drawn solely from group-level data, which can be misleading.

questions.question: The "attack rate" is most commonly used in:
questions.explanation: Attack rate measures new cases in a short period during outbreaks, especially for infectious diseases.

questions.question: Which of the following is a potential limitation of cross-sectional studies?
questions.explanation: Cross-sectional studies assess exposure and outcome at one time, limiting ability to determine which came first (temporality).

questions.question: Which statistical test is most appropriate for comparing the incidence of disease between two groups?
questions.explanation: Chi-square tests compare proportions such as incidence rates between categorical groups, while t-tests and ANOVA compare means.

questions.question: In which type of study are participants matched on confounders to control bias?
questions.explanation: Matching is commonly used in case-control studies to control confounding by selecting controls similar to cases on certain factors.

questions.question: What is "lead-time bias"?

options.text: ) Overestimation of survival time due to earlier detection by screening
) Bias due to loss to follow-up

questions.explanation: Lead-time bias occurs when screening advances diagnosis time without affecting survival, making survival seem longer.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a "surveillance system" in epidemiology?

options.text: ) A system for ongoing data collection and analysis of disease occurrence
) A treatment protocol for infectious diseases

questions.explanation: Surveillance systems monitor disease trends to guide public health actions.

questions.question: Which of the following terms describes the proportion of people exposed to a risk factor in a population?
questions.explanation: Prevalence of exposure measures how common a risk factor is in the population.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a "double-blind" study?

options.text: ) Only participants are unaware of group assignment
) Only investigators are unaware of group assignment
) Both participants and investigators are unaware of group assignment
) Neither group assignment nor outcomes are recorded

questions.explanation: Double-blinding prevents bias by keeping both parties unaware, reducing placebo and observer biases.

questions.question: The term "herd immunity" refers to:

options.text: ) Resistance of a population to disease spread when a high proportion are immune
) Immunity conferred only by natural infection

questions.explanation: Herd immunity occurs when enough people are immune, reducing disease spread and protecting non-immune individuals.
